Wagner Labor ArchiveElmer Holmes Bobst Library70 Washington Square South10th FloorNew York, NY 10012(212) 998-2630tamiment.wagner@nyu.eduThis finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace 2018-05-15T17:48:22Finding aid written in EnglishDescribing Archives: A Content Standard
Tamiment Library and Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives
Irish Repertory Theatre Records
Irish Repertory Theatre
O'Reilly, Ciarán
AIA.080
25.3 Linear Feet in 32 manuscript boxes, 2 half manuscript box, 6 record cartons, 1 flat box, 3 oversize flat boxes, and 1 flat file folder
25 videocassettes (vhs)
20 videocassettes (digital betacam)
12 sound discs (cd)
301.1 Gigabytes in 82,454 computer files
1988-2016 The Irish Repertory Theatre (IRT) was founded in New York, New York in 1988 by Charlotte Moore and Ciarán O'Reilly. The IRT produces Irish and Irish-American plays and musicals year-round. The Irish Repertory Theatre Records document 28 seasons of productions, from 1988 to 2016. Productions include The Plough and the Stars, The Irish...And How They Got That Way, and Finian's Rainbow. The records contain press and marketing materials, correspondence, scripts, legal documents, financial documents, original artwork, videos, and posters. The material consists of paper, born-digital, and audiovisual recordings. Materials in English. Materials are stored offsite and advance notice is required for use. Please contact tamiment.wagner@nyu.edu at least two business days prior to your research visit to coordinate access.
Scope and Contents
The Irish Repertory Theatre (IRT) Records document 28 seasons of productions staged by the Theatre, from 1988 to 2016. Productions include The Plough and the Stars, The Irish...And How They Got That Way, and Finian's Rainbow. The records document the work of various members and departments of the IRT, including Ciaran O'Reilly, the Producing Director; the Marketing Department; the General Manager; the Literary Department; and the Membership Manager. The records contain press and marketing materials, correspondence, scripts, legal documents, financial documents, original artwork, videos, and posters. The material consists of paper, born-digital, and audiovisual recordings. The press and marketing materials constitute the bulk of the collection and include programs, press releases, photographs, slides, and video recordings of productions and the IRT's annual benefits. The correspondence includes rejection letters; negotiations for rights, licensing, and productions; and communications with actors, producers, directors, and IRT members. The collection includes scripts used in productions and those submitted for the New Works Reading Series. The legal documents include contracts as well as court documents from legal proceedings in which the IRT was involved. The financial records include season and production budgets, and box office receipts and statements. The original artwork includes paintings and drawings for set designs and posters.
Arrangement
The records are arranged into the following four series, with two of these series further arranged into subseries.
Series I. Production Materials, 1989-2016
Series II. New Works Reading Series, 2005-2014
Subseries II. A. Selected Plays, 2006-2014
Subseries II. B. Rejected Script Files, 2005-2014
Series III. Administrative Records, 1990-2013
Subseries III. A. General Administrative Records, 1990-2013
Subseries III. B. Producing Director Records, 1994-2003
Subseries III. C. General Manager Records, 1997-2004
Subseries III. D. Membership Manager Records, 1999-2004
Subseries III.E. Marketing Department Records, 2003-2016
Series IV. Financial and Legal Records, 1989-2010
Historical Note
The Irish Repertory Theatre (IRT) was founded in New York, New York in 1988 by Charlotte Moore and Ciarán O'Reilly. As of 2018, Moore is the Artistic Director and O'Reilly is the Managing Director. The two met in the late 1980s in a Hudson Guild Theater production of Hugh Leonard's Summer, and decided to collaborate on a production of Sean O'Casey's The Plough and the Stars in September 1988. Their profits from that production were enough to stage another show, and in this way the IRT was founded. The IRT produces Irish and Irish-American plays and musicals year-round, both classics of Irish theater as well as new works by emerging Irish and Irish-American writers. The Theatre moved to its current location, as of 2018, in the Chelsea neighborhood of Manhattan in 1995. The IRT, its staff, and their productions have garnered critical acclaim and industry awards for their work.
Conditions Governing Access
Materials are open without restrictions, with the exception of certain files pertaining to legal proceedings in Series IV.
Audiovisual Access Policies and Procedures
Audiovisual materials have not been preserved and may not be available to researchers. Materials not yet digitized will need to have access copies made before they can be used. To request an access copy, or if you are unsure if an item has been digitized, please contact [repository contact information] with the collection name, collection number, and a description of the item(s) requested. A staff member will respond to you with further information.
Immediate Source of Acquisition
Donated by Ciarán O'Reilly in June 2016. The accession number associated with this gift is 2016.055.
Conditions Governing Use
Any rights (including copyright and related rights to publicity and privacy) held by the Irish Repertory Theatre, the creator of this collection, were transferred to New York University in June 2016 by Ciarán O'Reilly. Permission to publish or reproduce materials in this collection must be secured from the Tamiment Library.
Preferred Citation
Identification of item, date; Irish Repertory Theatre Records; AIA 080; box number; folder number; Tamiment Library/Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives, New York University.
Processing Information
Series were created according to the arrangement in which the collection was received and material was arranged together intellectually. Paper material for each series was brought together physically, with oversized paper materials, audiovisual material, and physical digital media housed together as appropriate. Separation sheets were created to sustain the intellectual relationship between items.
Paper material was housed in archival folders and boxes. Physical digital media and audiovisual material were housed in archival boxes. Duplicates in all formats were deaccessioned. Preservation photocopies were created for material originally printed on thermal fax paper.
Material in Series IV was determined to be protected under the attorney work-product doctrine. This was separated from the collection in March 2018 pending a decision regarding its inclusion in the collection.
Floppy disks, Zip disks, optical media, and one hard drive were forensically imaged, analyzed, and arranged in Forensic Toolkit.
New York University Libraries follows professional standards and best practices when imaging, ingesting, and processing born-digital material in order to maintain the integrity of the content.
Custodial History
The collection was transferred to Bobst Library from the Irish Repertory Theatre offices at 132 West 22nd Street, New York, NY 10011 on June 30, 2016. It was arranged by season, boxed and inventoried by Jessica Layman (Director of Marketing), in consultation with Lisa Fane (General Manager). Much of the collection was in temporary storage with The Padded Wagon, in the company's temporary offices at 345 Park Avenue, 17th floor, NYC, or in the company's temporary performance space at Theatre DR2, 103 East 15th Street while their permanent home was under renovation from 2014-2016.
Appraisal
Items of little research value were deaccessioned, including personal financial documents related to performers and customers, files related to staff performance, unopened commercial recordings of music and audiobooks unrelated to the Irish Repertory Theatre, clippings of reviews, Zip and floppy disks containing graphic design files used to create promotional ephemera for productions, and Theatre souvenirs. Off-air recordings of reviews of IRT productions were deaccessioned.
Physical Characteristics and Technical Requirements
Advance notice is required for the use of computer records. Original physical digital media is restricted. An access terminal for born-digital materials in the collection is available by appointment for reading room viewing and listening only. Researchers may view an item's original container and/or carrier, but the physical carriers themselves are not available for use because of preservation concerns.

Series I. Production Materials9.5 Linear Feetin 14 manuscript boxes, 2 record cartons, 3 oversize flat boxes98 Gigabytesin 24,739 computer files25 videocassettes (vhs)20 videocassettes (digital betacam)12 sound discs (cd)1988-2010
Arrangement
This series is arranged in chronological order by season, with no arrangement within each season.
Scope and Contents
This series documents 28 seasons of the Irish Repertory Theatre's productions and annual benefits, from 1989 to 2016. Material in this series consists of paper, born-digital, and audiovisual formats and includes promotional material, photographs, artwork, and material pertaining to legal and creative issues from early productions. The promotional material includes programs, postcards, posters, and press releases for individual productions; tickets, invitations, and programs for annual benefits; and issues of Prologue, the IRT's newsletter. The audiovisual material consists of video and digital audio and video recordings of select productions, including George M. Cohan Tonight!, Noctu, The Irish...And How They Got That Way, and annual benefits. Most productions are well documented through digital and print photographs and slides. Artwork includes drawings for set designs and posters.1988-1989 Season -- I Do Not Like Thee, Dr. Fell1981-198811-21988-1989 Season -- The Plough and the Stars198813-51988-1989 Season -- Yeats: A Literary Department Records3.8 Linear Feetin 9 manuscript boxes2005-2014
Arrangement
This series is arranged in two subseries, Subseries II. A. Selected Plays and Subseries II.B. Rejected Script Files.
Scope and Contents
This series documents the work of the Literary Department in evaluating submitted scripts and choosing works for the New Works Reading Series. Material in this series consists entirely of paper.Subseries II. A. Selected Plays1.7 Linear Feetin 4 manuscript boxes2006-2014
Arrangement
This subseries is arranged in chronological order by year and month in which the plays were performed by the IRT.
Scope and Contents
This subseries includes scripts chosen as part of the New Works Readings Series.20062006149-1915120072007152-1216120082008161-620092009167-9171-520102010176-12201120111713-14201220121715-16201320131717-1818120142014182-4Subseries II. B. Rejected Script Files2.1 Linear Feetin 5 manuscript boxes2005-2014
Scope and Contents
This subseries consists of script files submitted for the New Works Readings Series that were rejected by the IRT. The files include scripts, cover letters, curricula vitae, correspondence with authors, and reader reports.
Arrangement
The files in this subseries are loosely arranged in numerical order according to numbers assigned to each script as it was received by the Literary Department.0643-07152006-2007185-150716-07632007191-90796-06145, unnumbered files2005-2010, undated201-14Unnumbered files2006, undated211-2Reader reports2005-2014, undated213Rejection letters2006-2013214-12221-10231-2Series III. Administrative Records3.75 Linear Feetin 5 manuscript boxes and 1 oversize flat box203.1 Gigabytesin 57,715 computer files1990-2013
Arrangement
This series is arranged in five subseries: Subseries III. A. General Administrative Records, Subseries III. B. Producing Director Records, Subseries III. C. General Manager Records, Subseries III. D. Membership Manager Records, and Subseries III.E. Marketing Department Records.
Scope and Contents
This series documents various administrative offices and activities of the IRT, including the Producing Director, the General Manager, the Membership Manager, and the Marketing Department. Material in this series consists of both paper and born-digital material and includes correspondence, reports, budgets, photographs, and blueprints and floor plans.Subseries III. A. General Administrative Records1.3 Linear Feetin 3 manuscript boxes1990-2013
Arrangement
This subseries is arranged alphabetically by format or topic.
Scope and Contents
This subseries documents the IRT's cooperation with labor unions representing performers in New York City and the work of the IRT's Board of Directors. This subseries includes correspondence and contracts. Labor unions include the Actors' Equity Association, the United Scenic Artists, Local 802 Associated Musicians of Greater New York, and the Stage Directors and Choreographers Society. B. Producing Director Records0.2 Linear Feetin 1 manuscript box51.32 Megabytesin 1,159 computer files1994-2003
Arrangement
This subseries is arranged alphabetically by production title, topic, or format of material.
Scope and Contents
This subseries documents the work of Ciarán O'Reilly, co-founder and Producing Director of the IRT. Materials consists of paper and born-digital material and includes correspondence, budgets, notes, box office reports, and scripts. Correspondence includes negotiations with the Actors' Equity Association, requests for and acknowledgements of financial support for productions and the IRT, and licensing for scripts. This subseries contains material regarding the production of Grandchild of Kings, a production adapted from Sean O'Casey's autobiographies, directed by Harold Prince. This subseries also includes letters from O'Reilly to IRT members and sponsors, labor unions, and directors of productions at the IRT, including Tony Walton and Frank McCourt.Alive, Alive Oh!1991Electronic recordsTW_AIA_80_ER_74

Arrangement
This subseries is arranged alphabetically by production title, topic, format, or by the name of file's creator.
Scope and Contents
This subseries documents the work of two of the General Managers of the IRT, Shelley A. Troupe and Meridith Sommers. Responsibilities of this role documented in this subseries include managing day-to-day activities of the IRT, organizing the IRT's annual benefit, participating in advertising and development campaigns, managing the box office, and tracking compliance with the Actor's Equity Association (AEA) contracts. Material in this subseries consists of paper and born-digital material and includes correspondence, budgets, audits, contracts, photographs, box office reports, meeting agenda and minutes, and promotional material. This subseries includes Board of Directors meeting agenda and minutes and correspondence with the AEA, IRT members and sponsors, vendors, and insurance providers.Actors' Equity Association1998-2004Electronic recordsTW_AIA_80_ER_117

Arrangement
This subseries is arranged alphabetically by topic.
Scope and Contents
This subseries documents the work of two of Membership Managers of the IRT, Heather Kray and Eric Scott. Responsibilities of this role documented in this subseries include maintaining relationships with current theatre members as well as with advertisers. This subseries consists entirely of born-digital material and includes correspondence, spreadsheets, and promotional material.High level member letters 2001Electronic recordsTW_AIA_80_ER_163

Patron Circle : 2004-2009Subseries III.E. Marketing Department Records0.2 Linear Feetin 1 manuscript box192.6 Gigabytesin 51,099 computer files1988-2016
Arrangement
This subseries is arranged alphabetically by production title, format, or topic.
Scope and Contents
This subseries documents the work of the Marketing Department, including branding, promotion of the IRT and its productions, development of the capital campaign to renovate the theatre from 2014 to 2016, and the creation of a new website in 2012. The material in this subseries consists of paper and born-digital material and includes correspondence, promotional material, spreadsheets, photographs, blueprints, floor plans, and artwork. This subseries contains the Marketing Department's archive of promotional material for individual productions for seasons 2003-2004 to 2016-2017, material detailing the creation of the IRT's new website in 2012, guidelines for IRT branding standards, and artwork used in the creation of promotional material. Material detailing the development of the capital campaign includes a brochure and statement regarding the campaign, photographs and videos used to promote the campaign, and photographs of the theatre before, during, and after the renovation.After the Ball2004Electronic recordsTW_AIA_80_ER_168

2003 brochure : 2002-2003-2004 season flyer20032611Series IV. Financial and Legal Records2.5 Linear Feetin 6 manuscript boxes1989-2010
Arrangement
This series is arranged alphabetically by format or topic.
Scope and Contents
This series documents legal proceedings in which the IRT was involved, financial audits, and renovation of the IRT in 1995. This series consists of paper material and includes correspondence, contracts, court documents, audits, blueprints, and the IRT's by-laws and certificate of incorporation. Legal proceedings documented in this series include suits brought by the IRT against producer Robert Macken regarding his production of video recordings of The Irish...and How They Got That Way and Fathers to Daughters, and a suit brought by Charles Nelson Reilly against producer Michael Alden regarding Save It for the Stage: The Life of Reilly. The financial materials document the production of The Irish...and How They Got That Way and its 1997-1998 tour in New York City and Boston, Massachusetts; production budgets and box office totals for other IRT productions; and annual IRT audits. Material regarding the IRT's renovation include correspondence with the architect and blueprints detailing the renovation.
Conditions Governing Access
Two folders in this series are protected under the attorney work-product doctrine. They was separated from the collection in March 2018 pending a decision regarding its inclusion in the collection.Audits1990-20022612-15271-7By-laws and certificate of incorporation1989-1992278Fathers to Daughters1999-2000279-12281-633080.0017Grant application2010287Insurance claims1997-1998288The Irish…And How They Got That Way1999-2000289-19Macken, Bob1998-20022820-21291-12301-11421-2
